They are all Negroes and nearly all are dressed in glaring white - the women in garments like camisoles, the men in pants wh reach about to their shins: splayed, bare feet. Some of t faces bear the marks of heavy savage ornaments which have been removed, or of tatooing and scarring rituals which h been outlived -- torn nostrils, lips and ear lobes, a nec curiously thin and weak from the enormously heavy metal b which used to surround it. Some of the children are naked near-naked. Nearly everybody dutifully shares open hymnal but it is obvious that few, if any, can read. The singing most of them is weirdly shy and inchoate -- a little like that of a neighborhood audience when a group "sing" is im upon them. But on certain high phrases a glad, rich, wet  soprano lifts out large and happy, very child-like; and a big male voice bleats forth joyous, jazz-like improvement on the tune, a little off-key. Rose pulls out all the stops, spreads her knees, and pump like mad in her effort to drown out the ENGINE SOUND. Bro sweats and sings even harder, scowling, shaking his head. The singing is fraying out half to hell; the congregation a solid black wall of wandering eyes; a few pious convert frown or nudge at the less pious; a little group is coale toward the window. Rose's sense of artistic propriety is too much for her. T keep things going, she ought to play loud, but on the nex line -- "When I tread the verge of Jordan..." she shuts down to t vox humana and the tremolo and maintains that through -- "Bid my anxious fears subside." On this line, Allnutt appears and lounges against the fro door frame still drawing on his cigar. By the time of "hell's destruction," Allnutt becomes awar that a lighted cigar in church is bad manners, and, noddi casual apology to Brother, tosses it away onto the packed dirt, out of our sight. Instantly there is a hell of a  hullaballoo o.s., all in gibberish, against which the clo words of the hymn compete stridently. The less self-controlled of the flock are no longer singi and are craning their necks and rolling their eyes, but w just enough Sunday-Schoolish discipline to stay in their  places. The more pious, with effort, keep their eyes wher they belong and SING all the harder. IN QUICK SHOTS, Brot and Rose redouble their efforts. It may sound like bragging, Reverend,  but I'm mighty close to being in-di- spensable. Seein's how them Belgians  is too damn cheap to buy 'er a new  engine.
Rose joins them at the door.

Mornin', Miss.
Rose's prayer book is clamped under her sharp elbow. Her  walking is used to country, yet tight and spinsterish.

Don't care if I do.

Rose at dead center, Brother at her left, in profile, All at her right, opposite Brother, in profile. The room is s shaded against heat it is gloomy. The silence, gloom and  heat are stifling. Rose finishes fixing her own tea, and helps herself to br and-butter. She lifts her cup, not quite crooking her pin and sips. Allnutt still doesn't move; he is waiting for  Brother. Brother finishes and turns his page, and, withou shifting his eyes, finds his tea with a blind hand and bl drinks it and sets down the cup again. Allnutt, licensed, takes a big bite of bread-and-butter and picks up his cup and washes it down. By Rose's covered reaction, it is cle that she has been taught never, never to do this, but tha she expects no better of such as Allnutt. Allnutt sighs w and contentedly. This, too, is bad manners to Rose, but s takes it in her stride. They go on soberly eating bread-and-butter and drinking t The only SOUNDS are those of china, sipping, chewing and  swallowing. Nobody looks at anyone else. Brother and Rose are wholly, stiffly reposeful; they are used to this. All begins to get a little squirmy, like a child in church. T silence makes him visibly uneasy, but he tries not to sho his uneasiness. All of a sudden, out of the silence, there is a SOUND lik mandolin string being plucked. At first the sound is  unidentifiable, though instantly all three glance sharply up, each at the other two, then away; in the next instant they recognize what it is and each glances sharply,  incredulously, at the other two -- and then again, quickl away; then Brother and Rose glance with full recognition Allnutt, at the instant that he knows the belly-growl is  his. At the moment of recognition, he glances down at his middle with a look of embarrassed reproach. He glances up quickly and slyly -- hopeful they've missed it -- to find the eyes of both still fixed on him. The instant their ey meet they bounce apart like billiard balls, and fix on th first neutral object they happen to hit. Then Allnutt loo at them again: neither will look at him. All three lift their cups at the same moment, for a cover disembarrassing drink of tea. Rose and Allnutt simultaneo recognize what they are doing (Brother is pretending to r misses it, and goes ahead and drinks his), and both, at t same moment, lower their cups to saucers with an almost  simultaneous clink. W Brother has again put down his cup, Rose -- the tail of h eye on Allnutt -- picks up her cup and drinks, her eyes  carefully empty above the cup. Allnutt has his cup again the way to his mouth when his insides give out with a gro so long-drawn and terrible that Rose first flinches, then makes a noise across it with her spoon, stirring her tea. Brother tightens up like a fist, his first reflex being t this loud one is a calculated piece of effrontery. Allnut just endures it, with a look of suffering stoicism. When is over there is a tense silence. Allnutt slowly, slyly l up at Brother; he is stone. He looks to Rose; she is gazi far off into space. Allnutt is quite embarrassed, and kno they are. He does his best to relieve his own embarrassme and theirs.
(in a friendly, yet  detached tone) Just listen to that stomick of mine.

There is a silence. By their almost invisible reaction, i is clear that to just listen to that stomick of his, is t last thing they want to do. Allnutt is a bit chilled by t silence, but he tries again.
Way it sounds, you'd think I'd got  an 'eye-ener inside me.
A silence. Rose looks at Allnutt; their eyes meet; he attempts a fri smile. Her face goes stony with embarrassment and she loo quickly away. So does he.
(as soon as she can  manage it) Do have another cup of tea, Mr.  Allnutt.
Thanks, Miss, don't mind if I do.
He passes his cup, while she pours. There is a third grow not so bad. Allnutt says nothing. Then, after a pause:
Scuse me.
Rose looks stone deaf. She hands him his cup.
Much obliged, Miss.
He drinks some tea.
Queer thing, ain't it. (a silence) Wot I mean, wot d'you spose it is,  makes a man's stomick carry on like  that?
Bread and butter, Mr. Allnutt?
Thanks, Miss.

He takes some and eats. After a little chewing, his jaws  slow; he is expecting another growl and listens intently; does Rose; none comes, After a little, Allnutt relaxes an Rose relaxes at least to a state of armed truce. They are both munching methodically, eyes out of focus, when Broth takes a curiously official-mannered gulp of tea, sets dow his cup, and breaks the silence.
Herbie Morton's a bishop.
(thinking the remark  is addressed to him) Huh?
Who's that, dear?
Allnutt is pretty embarrassed to have said "huh."
Surely you remember Herbie Morton. (Rose looks doubtful) Blond, ruddy-complected chap, a bit  younger than me. He sang a solo at  the graduation exercises. "Holy,  Holy", I believe.
(dubiously) I think I remember. It was so long  ago.
Well, he's a bishop now.
Splendid.

I'd say Herbie was a bit younger  than I -- four or five years. (Rose pours more tea  into his cup) Surprising in a way. I mean -- well,  there was nothing outstanding about  him. He was no great shakes as a  student and he didn't have any more  than his share of the social graces. (a pause; he drinks  then eats bread and  butter, but with  rather less relish  than before) No doubt one does get ahead quicker  at home than in a foreign field...  And then, of course, he did marry  well.
Oh!

That manufacturer's widow. What was  his name? Briggs -- Griggs -- Briggs --  yes, Alfred Briggs. Soap flakes, I  think. Yes, Mrs. Alfred Briggs. (pause) Not to take anything away from Herbie. (pause) I am delighted for him.
Of course.
It was "Holy, Holy."
(pause) Yes.
A silence. Brother isn't even looking at his paper. Allnu stomach talks gently. They all accept it stoically.
(after quite a silence) There ain't a thing I can do about  it.
A silence.
More tea, Mr. Allnutt.
No, Miss, I reckon not. About time I  shoved off, if I'm gonna get back to  the mine by tomorra night.
(insincerely) Don't hurry, Mr. Allnutt.
(sure he is safe) Stay for dinner.
(shaking his head) Thanks all the same.
Brother pushes back his chair. Allnutt pushes back his ch and gets up. Rose pats her lips with her handkerchief, pu back her chair, and gets up.
Mr. Allnutt brought the marrow seed  at last.
Splendid.
I must say, though, they were forever  getting here.
Lucky they come through now, cause  it don't look like they'll be no  more mail for a while.
Why not?
Reckon the Germans'll hold it up.
(irate -- we sense a  background of  unpleasant relations  with the Germans) In heaven's name why?
Cause it looks like there's a war  on.
No. Really? Where, Mr. Allnutt?
Europe.
(with the patronizing  concern of one who  hears of another  Balkan brawl) Indeed! Between whom?
Oh, Germany, England, the whole --
(electrified) England!!
Right.
(pop-eyed) You mm -- you really mean war?
Wot they tell me. Germans claim the  British started it. British claim it  was the Germans. In any case, it's  war.
(with great intensity) But what's happened! What do you  know about it!
(like a whip) Rose! (she shuts up fast) Exactly, Mr. Allnutt, what has  happened?

Well, now, that's about all I can  remember. Oh yes -- France is in it,  too. She's with us, I fink. A lot 'o  them little countries are in it too --  Austria-Hungary, Spain, Belgium -- I  forget 'oo's with 'oom.
A pause.
(quiet desperation) And that is all you can tell us?
All I know. -- I'll try to pick up  some more, next trip to Limbasi.
I wonder to what extent we here shall  be affected.
None, I shouldn't think.
This is German territory.
Why would they want to bother a poor  devil of a missionary and his maiden  sister? -- beggin' your pardons.
We are enemy aliens.
Wot's the difference -- in this God- forsaken place?
(bridling) God has not forgotten this place,  Mr. Allnutt -- as my brother's  presence here bears witness.
No offence, Miss.
Another puzzled pause.
Really war.
Looks like it... Well, I better shove  off now. Many thanks for the tea.
He opens the door and goes through it.

Goodbye. And thank you.

Goodbye, Mr. Allnutt.

His boys jump action; curious villagers make way for him; the engine is going by the time he gets there. The boat backs out and s its course upstream; Allnutt turns and lifts a hand. Brot lifts a hand; Rose doesn't. The boat soon goes out of sig beyond trees. OVER the above, back-to-CAMERA, or quarter-profiled from rear as they idly watch his departure, Rose and Brother t quietly as follows:
Shouldn't we perhaps call him back?  Get to Limbasi while we can?

(with unction, yet  with dignity) The good shepherd does not forsake  his flock when wolves prowl. (a pause) Besides, I think Allnutt is very  probably right... I can't imagine  any reason why the Germans should  trouble us.
No, I suppose not.

By now, the boat is pulling out; Brother and Allnutt exch their not very friendly waves. Rose looks idly after Alln in Sunday boredom. Nothing is said for a few seconds afte the boat vanishes; the SOUND of the engine dwindles.
(awed, and moved) War. England. Just think!

I try to study -- so hard. I haven't  had the start some have: 'Ebrew;  Greek -- no -- facility. If only  there were more time. Well, if I  can't pass the examinations, I can  volunteer. I can be a missionary.  Rose, too. Not comely among maidens,  but she can become a servant in the  house of the Lord. Yes, even for  such as she, God finds a goodly use.
There is deep pain on Rose's face. She almost wants to sa something, but knows the senselessness of it. She just ke looking at him and listening.

(with calm, resolve,  acceptance) I'm going to put my books away, Rose.  I'm not going to study any more. If  I don't pass, it only means that God  has other work for me. Thy will be  done. (in a different voice,  secret, piteous,  impassioned) But, Lord, if it be Thy Will, O let  me distinguish myself and give me a  call here in England, right here at  home, Lord. Mother will be so proud,  Lord. Abash and put to shame all  them that revile me and persecute me  for Thy Name's sake. (whispering; pleading) Lord, I have tried so hard.
He is silent; she is motionless. Slowly LIFT CAMERA, losi Brother, CENTERING ROSE IN CLOSE UP.

over SOUND of expiring engine and rattle of anchor chain, reacting to his first sight of the vanished village. what we see of it from his angle. Since he is lower than village, all we can see is a lot of abnormal, empty sunli

He is wary, but knows he must investigate. He goes oversi almost out of the SHOT, stepping across a stump to shore. SWING WITH HIM. He is still careful and uneasy. through the screen door, from inside, as he comes up the  quietly creaking steps, sensitive to the mood of a kind o desolation different from that of the village; uneasy. He crosses the porch very quietly, again hesitates, peers th the gray screen door into the dark interior, and raps rat timidly.
(o.s., a dry quiet  voice with the calm  of exhaustion in it) Come in, Mr. Allnutt.

Her voice startles him as much as it should ourselves. He peers again, forehead wrinkled like a monkey's. He can't her. He shyly opens and comes through the door, mumbling  something apologetic and subversal. As he catches sight of her, SWING CAMERA to RIGHT, losing him, and PICK ROSE UP, MEDIUM CLOSE. She is past the angl of visibility from the screen door. She is in a wicker ro chair, sitting quite primly, working with those rings on  which embroidering is done. She glances up at him with ey like fused glass -- then quickly back to her needlework. is clear by the over-precision of her motions, and their  rigidity and tension, that she is under great strain, but this is to be keyed low and simple.
He watches her; he knows enough to keep quiet; he waits;  becomes aware of his muddy feet and quietly tries to clea one against the calf and shin of the other leg.
She does a couple more stitches, obtains sufficient contr of herself, and lowers the needlework into her lap.
(quietly, as before) Thank God you've come.
Nobody has ever thanked God in connection with him before His reaction is quiet, but clearly this is a surprising a novel experience. He says nothing.
(o.S.) Sit down, Mr. Allnutt.
Don't mind if I do.
He walks into:
He sits on the edge of a chair and jockeys it, shyly, a l nearer her.
So they got here afore I did, eh?
Yes, they got here. Just after you  left.
No!
She says nothing.
Couldn't a been more wrong, could I?  Bout the Germans.
(a quieter, remote  voice) Burning villages.

That's to keep the natives from  runnin' away. No place to come back  to. Been doin' it all over, they  told me up at Limbasi. The Germans  are gonna train 'em into an army and  try to take over the whole of Africa.
Poor helpless natives!

It was the same up at the mine when  I got back from Limbasi. A clean  sweep of everything. Just plain luck  I was on the river. They could  certainly use my launch and what's  in 'er, too. Blastin' gelatine, Miss.  Eight boxes of it. An' a lot of canned  grub. An' cylinders of oxygen an'  hydrogen for that weldin' job on the  crusher. Lots o' stuff.
(same dead voice) Oh, trust them.

But as it 'appens, I got the stuff --  an' the launch. Only I've got no  crew, an' she ain't an easy boat to  run single-'anded. Cause them two  boys o' mine just skipped in the  night. Don't know if they were scared  o' me or the Germans.
(quietly, always) They are fiends out of hell... His  whole life's work smashed. Ruined.  In a few minutes.
The Reverend, eh? (Rose nods) Where's 'e now, Miss?
(pause; quietly) He's dead.
I say, that's too bad! Pretty rough  on you, Miss. (embarrassed; trying  to keep the ball  rolling) What'd 'e die of, Miss?
They killed him.
(really a little  surprised and shocked) Well, now that's just awful! If  they'll up and shoot a Reverend, who  couldn't do 'em a bit a 'arm, there  ain't nobody safe.
They didn't shoot him, Mr. Allnutt.  But they are accountable to God just  as surely as if they had.
'Ow d'you mean, Miss?
They broke his heart. He didn't take  care of himself. He didn't want to  live.
She is looking into his eyes as if daring him to doubt or disagree. He is timid, perceptive and kind enough not to  argue with her. After a moment, he avoids her eyes.
Well, Miss that's cert'nly too bad,  that's all I can say. (both are quiet and  he is uneasy in the  silence. Making  conversation) When'd 'e die, Miss?
Early this morning. (an odd gesture) He's in there.
Hey!
I beg your pardon?
'Scuse it, Miss. (delicately) Wot I mean to say is -- the climate  'n all -- quicker you get 'im under  ground the better, if you don't mind  me sayin' so.
Rose nods.
(getting up) Got a shovel?
Behind the bungalow.
Right. -- Tell ya wot. While I'm  diggin' the grave, you get yer things  together, Miss -- all the things ya  want to take. Then we can clear out  of 'ere.
Clear out?
Germans might come back any time.
Why should they? They left nothing.
Oh, they'll come back, all right.  Lookin' for The African Queen. They'd  dearly love to get their 'ooks on  'er. She's the only power boat on  the river.
Where will we go?
I thought, Miss, 'ow we might find  somewhere quiet behind an island.  Then we could talk about what to do.
(a pause; then with  quick decision) I'll get my things ready.
Fine, Miss, I'll be quick's I can.
He starts for the front door.
Thank you, Mr. Allnutt.
You'd do the same for me, Miss.
As he thinks it over, he begins to wonder, literal-minded whether she really would. He goes on out.

They stand on opposite sides of the new grave. At its hea is an improvised cross, two pieces of wood carefully and  securely wired together. Rose is reading the last lines of the burial service from Methodist or Presbyterian prayerbook. She reads rather badly; (i.E., with the Protestant shadin of "expressiveness") yet between the language and the con between restraint and deep emotion in her voice, it is qu moving. Allnutt, while she reads, is trying to pay polite attention; he even says "Amen", and such, in a sheepish k of way. But his eyes keep sliding uneasily to the jungle; the Germans really do worry him. When she has finished, she stands very silent, for longer than he can take. He tries reasonably hard, but finally h has to speak.
Well, Miss, let's get outa here while  the gettin's good.

Rose, without looking at him or at the grave, and without speaking, walks away; he picks up his spade and follows. MEDIUM SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT at the edge of the porch. Rose pauses, looks over towards Brother's grave for the l time. Allnutt stands beside her, carrying her suitcase, n wanting to hurry her again, but wishing she'd get a move

head_text.subj: FROM THE INSIDE EDGE OF THE PORCH

text: By the turn of her head, our eye is led across the scarif clearing. We see the stunted cross and the overwhelming j and, perhaps, a little of the chapel.
(really meaning it;  but very restrained  and prim) It was very kind of you, Mr. Allnutt,  to think of the cross.
Shucks. Just seemed like he oughta  have one, him a Reverend 'n all.

Rose walks down the steps and towards the river. Allnutt  eagerly keeps pace. We SWING the CAMERA losing the grave, and passing and losing the chapel, and centering them get smaller along the bare ground in the hot sunlight, bringi in the river beyond them.
(o.s.) Careful now, Miss. Watch your step.  That's right.
PAST BOW) and keeping the noisy SOUND of the water. We pi up Rose and Allnutt as Allnutt helps her aboard. In her l and somewhat narrow skirt she is distinctly old-maidish.
(with the upward  English inflection --  a little as if he  had passed her a  teacup) Thank -- you?

Allnutt steps aboard. MEDIUM SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Rose sits down at the rea of the boat and looks around her. Her feet are drawn unde her and knees close together and hands lightly folded on knees (perhaps a lady's scrap of handkerchief in one hand as prim, genteel and ladylike as if, on a holiday afterno she were about to be rowed across an artificial lake fift yards wide. And that is more or less the way she glances  about her in her new surroundings -- politely and  restrainedly, as if a little critical of a parlor somewha humbler than her own. (This SHOT, at the very beginning of her voyage, is to be quite touching, delicate and ironical, and through her ve genteelism and total unconcern for what she is up against an unawareness -- we begin already to sense her complete  intrepidity.) Allnutt pauses to light up a cigarette before getting to  work. He hangs the cigarette inside his upper lip. This  cigarette, dead or alive, is a chronic fixture with Allnu Allnutt kneels in the bottom of the boat and addresses hi to the engine. He hauls out a panful of hot ashes and dum them overside with a sizzle and a splutter. He fills the  furnace with fresh wood from a pile beside him, and soon  smoke appears from the funnel, and we hear the ROAR of th draught. The engine begins to sigh and splutter, and then begins to leak gray pencils of steam. Allnutt peers at hi gauges, thrusts in some more wood, and then leaps forward around the engine, displaying monkeyish agility in handli more tasks than he quite has the hands or the stamina for With grunts and heaves of the small windlass, he hauls in the anchor, the sweat pouring from him in rivers. We see  already that he is physically not a strong man. Allnutt thrusts mightily at the muddy bank with a long po snatches the pole on board again, and then rushes aft to tiller.
'Scuse me, Miss.

He sweeps her aside unceremoniously (she is astonished bu quickly reassembles herself) and he puts the tiller over  just in time to save the boat from running into the bank. CAMERA IN on Rose, resettling her plumage, and on Allnutt the tiller. The river bank starts to swing in square to t stern. Their eyes are past the CAMERA. MEDIUM SHOT -- (MOVING WITH BOAT) -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Ros is deeply sad and very tired, but a very quiet kind of  exhilaration is already growing in her; and still more  clearly, her calm and tremendous, unreflecting resolutene begins to show. A pause.
Mr. Allnutt.
Yerss...?
What are the chances of our getting  out through Limbasi on the railway  to the Coast?
The railway was in German 'ands when  I was in Limbasi -- and by this time  Limbasi is too, I'll bet.
Then how do we get out, Mr. Allnutt?

You got me, Miss. (after a pause) We've got 'eaps of grub 'ere, Miss,  so we're all right, far as that goes.  Two thousand cigarettes, two cases  of gin. We could find a good 'iding  place an' stay there for months if  we want to.
Rose's astonishment at this suggestion keeps her from  replying.

(rattling on) I spose there's goin' to be a fight.  If our troops come from the sea,  they'll attack up the railway to  Limbasi, I spose. In that case, the  best thing we could do would be to  wait round down 'ere an' just go up  to Limbasi when the time came. -- On  the other 'and, they might come down  from British East, an' if they do  that we'd 'ave the Germans between  us and them all the time. Same if  they came from Rhodesia or Portuguese  East. We're in a bit of a fix,  whichever way y'look at it, Miss. (abruptly) Mind takin' the tiller, Miss?

Allnutt stands up and Rose takes over the tiller, holding the iron rod resolutely. Allnutt goes to his engine and i violently active once more. He pulls open the furnace doo and thrusts in a few sticks of fuel; then he scrambles up into the bow and stands balanced on the cargo. The river studded with islands so that it appears as if there were dozen different channels.
Port a little, Miss.
CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE She is confused by the command.
(o.s.) Pull it over this side, I mean. --  That's it! Steady!

MOVING SHOT -- THE LAUNCH The boat crawls up a narrow tun of leaf and shade. (If color photography is used, the SHO would be startingly juicy and green -- many shades of gre reflected in rich brown water.) Allnutt comes leaping back over the cargo and shuts off t engine; the propeller stops vibrating. Allnutt dashes into the bow again. Just as the trees (SHO PAST ROSE and her interest in it) begin apparently to mov forward again as the current overcomes the boat's way, he lets go the anchor with a rattling CRASH, and almost with a jerk the launch comes to a standstill. A great silence seems to close in on them -- the silence a tropical river at noon. The only SOUND is the subdued r and gargle of the water. The sober air is filled with a  strange light -- a green light. Allnutt turns from his work at the anchor. He and Rose lo about them and at each other, for a moment mysteriously  bemused by the stillness and by the beauty of the place. sudden quietness and the look of the place are richly  romantic; the two people are quieted by it, but they are  wholly unaware of any such potentiality between them. The are just a couple of oddly assorted derelicts who hardly  even know each other, and don't care for what little they know. A pause.

So far so good. 'Ere we are safe an'  sound, as you might say. (he beams upon his  surroundings) Not too bad a spot, is it, Miss, to  sit a war out in? All the comforts  of 'ome, includin' runnin' water.
He laughs at his joke and is disappointed when Rose does join him.
I'm afraid, Mr. Allnutt, that what  you suggest is quite impossible.
'Ave you got any ideas? (he takes a map out  of his pocket and  hands it to her) 'Ere's a map, Miss. Show me the way  out an' I'll take it.
Rose opens the map and starts studying it.
(after a while) One thing sure; our men won't come  up from the Congo, not even if they  want to. They'd 'ave to cross the  lake, and nothin' won't cross the  lake while The Louisa is there.
(blankly) The Louisa? What's that?
It's an 'undred-ton German steamer,  Miss, and she's the boss o' the lake  'cause she's got a six-pounder.
What's that?
A gun, Miss. The biggest gun in  Central Africa.
I see.

If it wasn't for The Louisa, there  wouldn't be nothin' to it. The Germans  couldn't last a month if our men  could get across the lake... But all  this doesn't get us any nearer 'ome,  does it, Miss? Believe me, if I could  think wot we could do...
This river, the Ulanga, runs into  the lake, doesn't it?
Well, Miss, it does; but if you was  thinkin' of goin' to the lake in  this launch -- well, you needn't  think about it any more. We can't  and that's certain.
Why not?

Rapids, Miss. Cataracts and gorges.  There's an 'undred miles of rapids  down there. Why, the river's even  got a different nyme where it comes  out on the lake to what it's called  up 'ere. It's the Bora down there.  No one knew they was the same river  until that chap Spengler --
He got down it. I remember.

Yes, Miss, in a dugout canoe. 'E 'ad  half a dozen Swahili paddlers. Map  makin', 'e was. In fact, that's 'is  map you're lookin' at. There's places  where this ole river goes shootin'  down there like out of a fire 'ose.  We couldn't never get this ole launch  through.

While he talks, Rose begins to look restive and vague, as well as discouraged. By the time he is through, she has s up, CAMERA WITH HER; she hardly hears him. She strolls a  little aimlessly PAST THE CAMERA, which SWINGS TO CENTER BACK as she walks forward. As if half in her sleep, she  sidesteps the engine. REVERSE ANGLE -- ROSE (SHOOTING FROM THE BOW) as Rose  sidesteps. She walks toward CAMERA into MEDIUM CLOSE UP,  eyes glazing with dreamlike concentration. She sees somet before and below her eye-level; stops, focusing on it. CLOSE SHOT -- (FROM ROSE'S ANGLE) -- THE GELATINE CASES n marked or labeled as such.
(o.s.) Mr. Allnutt --
Yes, Miss.
What did you say is in these boxes  with the red lines on them?
MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT -- ALLNUTT -- (FROM ROSE'S ANGLE) loung and lazy.
That's blastin' gelatine, Miss.
(head towards him,  away from CAMERA) Isn't it dangerous?

Bless you, no, Miss, that's safety  stuff, that is. It can get wet and  not do any 'arm. If you set fire to  it, it just burns. You can 'it it  wiv an 'ammer and it won't go off --  at least I don't fink it will. It  takes a detonator to set it off.  I'll put it over the side if it  worries you though.
(sharply, yet absently  as she turns into  CAMERA) No. We may need it.
Allnutt keeps watching her idly, a little amused and very slightly contemptuous. She wanders away from the boxes, e downcast in thought, and pauses again.
(not looking up) Mr. Allnutt --
Yeah?

head_text.subj: THE STEEL CYLINDERS IN BOTTOM OF BOAT

text: (o.s.) And what are these queer long round  things?
Them's the oxygen and hydrogen  cylinders, Miss. Ain't no good to  us, though. Next time I shift cargo,  I'll dump 'em.
(sharply, yet still  more subconsciously  and quietly than  before) I wouldn't do that.
She keeps looking down at them, musingly, "subconsciously while CAMERA CREEPS CLOSER to her.
They look like -- like torpedoes.

"Torpedoes" is spoken over: INSERT -- CYLINDERS -- a new and most deadly possible loo SHOT of the cylinders. STILL CLOSER SHOT -- ROSE Slowly she raises her eyes from floor angle to normal; a wild light is dawning in her eye
(in the voice almost  of a medium) Mr. Allnutt --
She turns very slowly towards him.
(a little bit smug) I'm still right here, Miss, and on a  thirty-foot boat there ain't much of  any place else I could be.
MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE -- (FROM ALLNUTT'S ANGLE) walki slowly and somewhat portentously towards him.
(full of the wild  light) You're a machinist, aren't you? Wasn't  that your position at the mine?
CAMERA ADVANCING on him at Rose's pace, stopping, looking down, during his last six or eight words.
(comfortably) Yeah, kind of fixer. Jack of all  trades and master o' none, like they  say.
CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE -- (FROM ALLNUTT'S ANGLE) disconcertin close.
Could you make a torpedo?
(o.s.) Come again, Miss?
Could you make a torpedo.

You don't really know what you're  askin', Miss. It's this way, you  see. A torpedo is a very complicated  piece of machinery what with  gyroscopes an' compressed air chambers  an' vertical and horizontal rudders  an' compensating weights. Why, a  torpedo costs at least a thousand  pounds to make.
He relaxes; his manner is "The State Rests." SWING CAMERA to center Rose, still perched on the gunwale
(after a short pause;  unperturbed) But all those things, those gyroscopes  and things, they're only to make it  go, aren't they?
Uh-huh. Go -- and hit what it's goin'  after.
(at the height of her  inventiveness; the  words triumphant and  almost stumbling out) Well! We've got The African Queen.
She stands up with these words, CAMERA RISING with her,  SHOOTING FROM A LITTLE BELOW; her eager eyes are constant on Allnutt.
If we put this -- this blasting stuff --  in the front of the boat here -- and  a -- what did you say -- deno --  detonator there, why that would be a  torpedo, wouldn't it?
CLOSE SHOT -- ALLNUTT looking up at her, greatly amused,  almost sardonically admiring her.
(o.s.) Those cylinders. They could stick  out over the end, with that gunpowder  stuff in them and the detonator in  the tips where the taps are.
Then if we ran the boat against the  side of a ship, they'd -- well, they'd  go off, just like a torpedo. (somewhat doubtfully,  in a return to her  submissive feminine  habit) Wouldn't they?

(tremendously amused;  gravely) That might work. (humoring her along,  and a little taken  in by his own fondness  for makeshift) Them cylinders'd do right enough. I  could let the gas out of 'em and  fill 'em up with the gelignite. I  could fix up a detonator all right.  Revolver cartridge'd do. (warming up to it, as  an impossible project) Why, sure, we could cut 'oles in the  bows of the launch, and 'ave the  cylinders stickin' out through them,  so's to get the explosion near the  water. Might turn the trick. But  what would 'appen to us? It would  blow this ole launch and us and  everything all to Kingdom come.

I wasn't thinking that we should be  in the launch. Couldn't we get  everything ready and have a -- what  do you call it -- a good head of  steam up and point the launch toward  the ship and then dive off before it  hit? Wouldn't that do?
Might work, Miss. But what are we  talkin' about, anyway. There ain't  nothin' to torpedo. 'Cause The African  Queen's the only boat on the river.
Oh, yes there is.
Is what?
Something to torpedo.
An' what's that, Miss?
The Louisa.
(on mention of The  Louisa, a blank,  silent stare of mock  amazement. Then,  patiently) Don't talk silly, Miss. You can't do  that. Honest you can't. I told you  before we can't get down the river.
Spengler did.
In a canoe, Miss!
Rose looks stubborn.
If a German did it, we can, too.
Not in no launch. We wouldn't 'ave a  prayer.
How do you know? You've never tried.
Never tried shootin' myself through  the 'ead, neither. (pause) Trouble with you is, you just don't  know nothin' about boats, or water.
A pause. They look at each other, Rose much more fixedly searchingly than Allnutt
In other words, you are refusing to  help your country in her hour of  need, Mr. Allnutt?
I didn't say that.
Well then --!
(sighs deeply) 'Ave it your own way, Miss -- only  don't blame me, that's all.

Allnutt stands perplexed and inarticulate, his cigarette  drooping from his upper lip. His wandering gaze strays fr Rose's feet, up her white drill frock to her face; he sta slightly at her implacable expression.
Very well, let's get started.
What! Now, Miss?
(impatiently) Yes, now. Come along.
There isn't two hours of daylight  left, Miss.
We can go a long way in two hours.

Allnutt starts to speak; refrains; limps over to windlass and raises the anchor. Rose watches him. CAMERA PANS afte The African Queen as Allnutt backs her out into the chann then turns her nose downstream.

He is at the tiller -- back to CAMERA; Rose, standing loo downstream. The Mission clearing on the bank, which they approach, is unobserved by both of them. Presently pencil of steam begin coming out of the engine. Allnutt, feeling that it requires his attention, signals to Rose, who take his place at the tiller. Allnutt goes to the engine and b to tinker.
A lot o' the time I'm going to 'ave  more than enough to do, keepin' the  ole engine goin.' So you might as  well start learnin' to steer right  now.
Rose nods. Her hand takes a firmer, more authoritative ho on the tiller.
(continuing) She ain't no one-man boat, the Queen.  Not in the shape she's in.
Rose again shifts her hand a little; and she sits up very straight with her new sense of responsibility.
Know port from starboard, Miss?
I've heard of them.
Well, that's port -- (gesturing) -- an' that's starboard.
Isn't that a bit -- well, silly? Why  not just say left and right?

Well, spose yer facin' the other way  in the boat an' I say "to the left."  You might think I meant to your left,  see, an' move to starboard. It's the  boat ya gotta think of, see? So port's  always that side -- (gesturing) -- an' starboard, that -- an'  forrard's always up there an' aft is  where we are right now -- no matter  what way we're turned around or the  boat is headed.
Why yes, I see. It's really quite --  sensible, isn't it?
Uh huh. Okay. Now go easy, Miss --  light on the tiller. Now steer her  just a little to starboard.
Rose puts the tiller to starboard; the launch swerves a l to port. She looks at Allnutt, bewildered. Allnutt is qui amused.

Okay, Miss, just straighten her out  again. (using flat hands to  demonstrate) Now looky here. Here's yer tiller. (he extends his right  hand) Here's yer rudder. (he extends his left  hand, below and beyond  his right) They're joined. Tiller sets the  rudder, rudder steers the boat. (he slants both hands  rigidly to one side)
(eagerly) Oh, I see!
Rose lifts her own hand from the tiller to show; the boat yaws abruptly.
Tiller, Miss!
Rose, startled, grabs the tiller and rights her course.
(blushing) Sorry.
'S all right, just don't never do  that, 's all.
Why, the water -- well -- pushes  against the rudder, where it turns,  and -- sort of drags the boat that  way. Turns it.
You're catchin' on fine, Miss.
Rose looks as pleased as if she had personally invented t rudder.
Now a little to starboard, Miss.  Easy now. (Rose does it right) Fine. Now a little to port. (Rose does it right)
Is that all there is to it?
Well, ya gotta know how to read the  river.
Read?
Ya gotta know the water an' what's  under it, that ya gotta steer clear  of.
Steer clear of. Why, that's where  that expression comes from.
(uninterested) Uh huh. Mostly ya can tell it by the  surface o' the water. Now ya see  that long thing out there like a "V"  kinda?
a long, quiet "V" on the water.
(o.s.) That always means a snag. Limb  stickin' up from a dead tree; likes  o' that.
Stay off them "Vs," they're murder.
Rose looks very seriously, almost reprimandingly, towards the "V."

head_text.subj: A DIFFERENT PART OF THE RIVER

text: The higher light shows it is later in the morning. In the distance, past smooth water, a choppy patch.
(o.s.) Now all that little choppin', them's  shallas, Miss.
Rose's eyes move from the shallows to steering; she shift course a little, and a long "V" trails past.

as he waves at the engine and shouts something that is dr out by the ROAR of the waters.

gesticulating frantically. He moves forward into a CLOSE and shouts:
(shouting) Need fuel! We got to get fuel!
She nods, to show her understanding of their plight.

There is a natural dam ahead, only broken in the center, there the water piles up and tumbles over in a vast green hump. The launch puts her nose and heaves up her stern as she hits the piled-up water; then she shoots down the slo landing with a crash on the high green waves beneath the  waterfall.

Green water comes boiling over the port deck and into the boat. Allnutt must hold onto the engine to keep from bein swept off his feet. It seems as though The African Queen doomed to put her nose deeper and deeper into the torrent until she will submerge entirely -- but at the last possi moment she shakes herself loose and comes clear.
as she throws her weight on the tiller
(shouting) Stop the engine!
as he obeys dazedly.

The maneuver was nicely calculated; the launch's momentum carries her through the edge of the eddy into the slack w under the lip of the dam. She comes up against this natur pier with hardly a bump, and instantly a trembling Allnut is fastening painters to rocks.
Whew!!!

as she starts to rise, but finding herself weak in the kn sits back momentarily. Despite an empty feeling in her st and a pounding heart, she wears a smile of satisfaction. She looks around. They are moored in what must be one of loveliest corners of Africa. There are numerous shelves o the high banks bearing flowering plants which trail shimm wreaths down over the rocks. A beam of sunlight reaches o the edge of the gorge and turns its spray into a dancing  shadow. The NOISE of the fall is not deafening, but rathe pleasant musical accompaniment to the joyful SINGING of t river.
How lovely!
Allnutt enters the SHOT from BEHIND CAMERA. She turns her smile on briefly. then raises her eyes again to the hangi gardens above.
(continuing) Lovely, isn't it.

(following her gaze) It is at that. (he laughs suddenly) We sure pulled it off, didn't we,  Miss? Sucked the Germans in proper.  They were so surprised to see the  ole African Queen -- they didn't  think of shootin' at us till we were  almost past. They didn't believe  anybody'd try to get down these  gorges. Didn't believe nobody could.  Well, we showed 'em, didn't we? (Rose nods) Not that I'd like to do it every day  of the week. We took on enough water  to sink anything else that floats.  He reaches for the pump and goes to  work.
(coming out of her  reverie) Here -- let me do that.
(protesting) Oh, no, Miss.
Please let me.
All right -- but don't wear yourself  out... I'll pick up some wood.
Rose applies herself to the pump. It takes her a little w to get into the right rhythm, and when she does, even so  small a thing as this brings a thrill of achievement.
I hardly know what happened after  Shona. Everything's a jumble. I have  no idea how far we've come or whether  it's morning or afternoon or --
as Allnutt gathers wood on the bank.
I guess you were too busy, Miss, to  pay attention to anything but what  you were doing.
(hesitantly) Did I -- do all right?
(with deep feeling) Better'n all right, Miss...
Her face flushes with pride.
as he goes back onto the boat carrying an armload of wood He is limping a little. He lets the wood fall by the engi then sits down and begins to unlace his canvas shoe.
Picked up a thorn on the bank, I  guess. Went right through the rubber  sole.
Let me.

On her knees, she slips the shoe off; she takes his slend rather appealing foot into her hands. She finds the place entry of the thorn and presses it with her finger-tips wh Allnutt twitches and jumps with absurd ticklishness.
No, there's nothing there now.
She lets his foot go.
Thank you, Miss.
He lingers on the bench, gazing up at the flowers, while  Rose lingers on her knees at his feet.
(a certain awe in his  tone) It is pretty at that.

Rose looks up at his face. There is something appealing,  almost childlike about the little man as he looks wonderi around. Her expression grows tender; she would like to pe him. He looks down at her. She averts her eyes.
It reminds me -- that waterfall does --  of --
Allnutt never tells what it reminds him of. He puts out h hand toward Rose. She catches it -- to hold it, not to pu it away. Allnutt comes down to his knees and they are in  each other's arms.

as a few slanting rays of the sun strike her funnel. Vapo still cling to the surface of the river. Over the SOUND o the waterfall, comes the tuneful SINGING of a bird. Prese Rose's figure is revealed moving about.

as she pours tea into two cups, and moves with them towar the stern, CAMERA PANNING WITH HER as she crosses to the  sleeping Allnutt. CAMERA MOVES into CLOSE TWO SHOT as she kneels beside Allnutt and puts one tea-cup down close to outstretched hand.
(softly) Mr. Allnutt. I mean -- dear.
(opening his eyes) Well now -- blimey! This is more  like it.
Breakfast in bed.
Two spoonfuls of sugar is right,  isn't it?
(nods) Fancy your building the fire and all --  while I slept.
Rose regards him tenderly for a long moment; then, with a birdlike movement, she kisses him on the cheek. Allnutt p his arms around her.
Dear -- there's something I simply  must know.
What's that?
(after a blushing  interval) What's your first name?
Charlie.
(to herself like a  schoolgirl) Charlie... Charlie... Charlie...
Give us another kiss.
(her arms around him,  kissing him) Charlie! Charlie dear...
They hold each other for a while. Then she slips out of h arms, hands him his cup and they begin stirring their tea Rose looks at the beauty all around them.
(her eyes suddenly  wet) This must be one of the loveliest  places in all Africa.

I've been around a bit and I must  say I never seen no place to compare  with it in the whole world. Kinda  hate to leave it. (hastily, as though  he fears being  misunderstood) Not that I ain't all for goin' on,  Y'unnerstand. (she gives his hand a  squeeze) Do you spose that last big cataract  coulda been Ulanga Falls? As I  remember the map, it was just a little  way down from Shona. And if it was  Ulanga, there ain't no more big  cataracts between us an' the lake.
How much farther is the lake, Charlie?
Oh -- 'bout two 'undred miles.
They are quiet a moment. Abruptly, Rose gets final, and  energetic -- swallows the last of her tea in that manner stands up, a touching blend of spinsterish edginess and  blossoming female softness.
Well, I suppose it's time we were on  our way.

Rose takes her place at the tiller and Allnutt goes forwa in unquestioning obedience. He is boss of the family, but she is boss of the boat and the voyage. He casts off, and starts up the engine. Again The African Queen is under wa

at the tiller. She looks back, drinking in the place with her eyes. She wants never to forget a single detail. Alln enters the SCENE -- puts his arm around her, and stands  looking back at the loveliest place in the world.
We see the waterfall and the flowers withdraw. The SOUND the waterfall still dominates -- a SOUND of serene,  inexhaustible vitality like that of their bloodstream.
(in a broken voice) Give us another kiss, old girl.
They kiss, as the boat is swept into motion.

The river is smooth, swift and fairly straight. The launc passes some hippos bathing in the shallows. The deep, swi running channel carries her to within a few yards of the  great beasts. Allnutt and Rose shout at them and wave their arms. The h squeal like pigs. Allnutt imitates the SOUND, a feat whic Rose finds to be funny beyond words. She laughs until it painful and she has to hold her side. Allnutt laughs too, between squeals, hugely delighted with the success of his imitation. Just as Rose is about able to control her laug he squeals once again, which sends her off into fresh pea of mirth.
Stop, Charlie -- stop it!

Their laughter begins to die down, then starts up again.  Finally comes a moment of silence while they struggle to  regain breath, and during that moment Allnutt hears a SOU which is not at all funny.
Rosie, listen... You 'ear wot I 'ear?
OVER the SOUND of the engine, comes a distant ROAR.
I guess that wasn't Ulanga Falls,  after all.
(soberly) I guess not.

Allnutt applies himself to the boiler, putting more wood adjusting the draft. The speed of the river increases, as does the DIN of the  approaching cataract. The African Queen begins to heave a the first waves of the race.
staring forward as she braces herself once more to hold t tiller steady.
as the waterfall comes into view, Allnutt in f.g. He throws her a swift, backward look.
scared, but game.
(calls) Goodbye, Charlie.
shouting an answer; his voice is lost in the UPROAR.

as she rears up and hangs for a moment at the crest of th waterfall. Then she shoots forward and down, finally to c in a tangle of currents below the waterfall. She shakes w the impact. Water flies back, high over the top of the fu then she surges on. There is a TEARING SOUND beneath, followed by a horrid  vibration which seems as if it will shake the boat to pie
(screams) Keep her going, Charlie!
opening the throttle. The devastating vibration increases
as she fights to keep the boat in mid-current, but someth is wrong with the steering.
(screams) Charlie!
He points toward the bank where a big rock juts out into river.

fighting the tiller. The boat swings around crabwise towa the rock, and it looks for a moment as though the stern w surely crash into it. Rose keeps the tiller hard over. Su enough, The African Queen comes all the way about, her bo to the shore, grounded; but the maneuver is not completel successful. Instantly she heels and rolls. A mass of wate comes boiling in over the gunwale. The boiler fire is  extinguished and a wild flurry of steam pours out.
Grabbing a painter, he leaps like an athlete into the whi eddy, gets his shoulder under the bows and heaves.

The bows slide off and the boat rights herself, wallowing three-quarters full of water. Instantly the current pulls her downstream. CAMERA PANS as Allnutt leaps up the face of the rock,  clutching the painter. He gives it a turn around an angle the rock and braces himself. His shoulder-joints crack as the rope tightens, but slowly the boat swings in to shore Five seconds later, she is safe, and Allnutt is making pa after painter fast to the shore.
standing on the bench in the stern, the water slopping at her feet. She manages a smile at Allnutt. She feels a lit sick and faint now that it is all over.
He sits down on a rock and grins back at her.
We nearly done it that time, didn't  we, Rosie.
as she sits on the gunwale. She doesn't wish to let her  weakness be seen. She forces herself to be matter of fact
I wonder how much we've lost.
Let's get this water out and see.
He swings himself aboard, splashes down to the waist and  fishes about for the pails.

as she tucks her skirt up into her underclothes as though she were a little girl at the seaside. CAMERA PANS with h to Allnutt. She takes a pail and the two of them go to  bailing, and conversation ceases with the effort.
He has gotten up a couple of floor boards in the waist, a is down on his knees inspecting the planking.

It's better than we coulda hoped  for. We 'aven't lost nothin', far as  I can see. 'Aven't damaged 'er skin  worth mentionin'. I shoulda thought  there'd been an 'ole in 'er  somewheres, after wot she's been  through.
What was all that clattering just  before we stopped?
We still got to find that out, old  girl.
How are we going to do that, dear?
I'll 'ave to go underneath and 'ave  a look.

He is out of his shirt and trousers in a jiffy. His drawe are the old-fashioned kind reaching to the knee and tying with a string behind. He picks up a rope and ties one end around his middle and gives the other end to Rose.
There ain't no other way. You stay  'andy with that rope -- case there's  a fancy current down at the bottom...  'Ere goes!
And over the side he goes. His feet remain in view for a  moment; then, kicking, they disappear.

head_text.subj: THE PROPELLER SHAFT OF THE LAUNCH

text: Allnutt swims into the picture, giving forth with bubbles He inspects the shaft.
leaning far over the stern, trying to glimpse what is  happening beneath The African Queen. Presently, Allnutt's head breaks the surface of the water.
(hovering anxiously  over him) Could you see anything, dear?
Yes.
With her help, he climbs back aboard, sits down on the be Rose sits beside him and waits for him to regain his brea She puts out her dry hand and clasps his wet one.
(dully) Shaft's bent to blazes like a  corkscrew, and there's a blade gone  off the prop.
We'll have to mend it, then.
Mend it! (he laughs bitterly) Not likely.
Why is that, dear? (he doesn't answer) What shall we have to do before we  go on?

I'll tell ya. (savage despondency  in his tone) I'll tell ya what we could do if we  was sittin' in the landin' slip at  Limbasi. We could pull this old tub  out an' take the shaft down an' 'aul  it over to the workshop where they'd  forge it straight again. An' then we  could write to the makers and get a  new prop. They might 'ave one in  stock 'cause this boat ain't over  thirty years old. An' while we was  waitin' we might clean 'er bottom  an' paint 'er. Then we could put in  the shaft an' the new prop an' launch  'er an' go on as if nothin' 'ad  'appened. -- But this ain't Limbasi,  an' so we can't.
(after a pause) Can't you get the shaft out without  pulling the boat on shore?
I dunno. I might. Means workin'  underwater. Could do it perhaps.
Well, if you were able to get the  shaft up on shore, could you  straighten it?
Ain't got no hearth. Ain't got no  anvil. Ain't got no coal. Ain't got  nothin'. An' furthermore, I ain't no  blacksmith.
(tapping her memory) I saw a Masai native working once.  Using charcoal... on a big hollow  stone. He had a boy to fan the  charcoal.
Yes, I've seen that, too! But I'd  use a bellows, myself -- make them  easy enough.
Well, if you think that would be  better.
(the engineer in him  taking over) There's 'eaps an' 'eaps of driftwood  up on the bank.
Why don't you try it?
(suddenly shying) No. It ain't no use, Rosie, old girl.  I was forgettin' that prop. There's  a blade gone.
Can't we go on the blades that are  left?
There's a torque. Prop wouldn't be  balanced. Wouldn't take five minutes  for the shaft to be like a corkscrew  again.
We'll have to make another blade.  There's lots of iron and stuff you  could use.
(ironically) And tie it on, I suppose.
(missing his irony) Yes, if you think that will do. But  wouldn't it be better to -- weld it?  That's the right word, isn't it?  Weld it on?
You're a one, Rosie. Really you are. (laughs)
Isn't weld the right word, dear? You  know what I mean even if it isn't,  don't you?
Oh, it's the right word, all right.

He laughs again. At first, Rose is afraid that his laugh caused by desperation, but when she sees that it is not, laughs with him. Directly they are in each other's arms, kissing as two pe might be expected to kiss on the second day of their  honeymoon.

working on the shaft. Now and then he bangs his hammer on the hull of the boat. Apparently he and Rose have a syste of signals. Just as he succeeds in loosening the bracket  supporting the shaft, a whim of the river expresses itsel in a fierce underwater swirl. Allnutt is turned upside do but he holds onto the bracket like grim death.
pulling in on the rope. Allnutt comes to the surface, dro the bracket into the boat.
(gasping) Swallered about half the river that  time.
You were down there an awfully long  time. I got scared.
Shaft is ready to come out now. It'll  be too heavy for me to swim up with.  I'll 'ave to walk with it in to  shore... Well, 'ere goes -- for the  last time, I 'ope.
Charlie.
Huh?
Let me help you.
'Ow do you mean?
She begins to peel off her clothes.
Wot d'you think you're goin' to do?
Go down with you.

An' get drownded? You don't know wot  it's like, Rosie. Them currents is  just fierce. (he shakes his head) Wot'll you be thinkin' of next! (he takes two deep  breaths) Well, 'ere goes. (After a third and  deeper breath, he is  gone.)

Allnutt swims into view, slides the shaft out through the bearings and begins to carry it toward shore. The current catches him. He loses his footing, regains it, only to fa again. The heavy shaft is too much for one man to handle. He is struggling vainly with it when into the SCENE swims Rose. She takes one end of the shaft, Allnutt the other, together they walk under water toward shore

Rose is working the bellows while Allnutt hammers patient Presently he lays aside the hammer and, using a taut stri judges the straightness of the shaft. Apparently he is pl with his work, for he grins at Rose and nods briefly.

If my old dad 'ad put me to  blacksmithin' when I was a kid, I  don't think I should never 'ave come  to Africa. I might've -- (a faraway look comes  into his eyes; he is  thinking about Charing  Cross on a Saturday  night; finally he  shakes himself) -- But then I shouldn't never 'ave  met you, Rosie old girl. (he goes back to  hammering) I wouldn't trade you for all the  fried fish shops in the world.
(protesting this  accolade) Oh, Charlie!
He slips a ring of wire over the end of the shaft and mov it up and down its length, testing the diameter.
(finally) Well, I guess it's just about as  good as I can get it -- And it didn't  take so long a time, neither.
Only a week.
The blade's a different proposition.  I'll 'ave to make it.

held in place on stone anvil with a pair of pliers; it is beginning to take shape under blows of Allnutt's hammer. pliers carry it over the other two blades, which are its  models, and turn it this way and that for purposes of  comparison.
getting the shaft, with its new propeller, back into posi
turning. SOUND of the engine, o.s. CAMERA TILTS UP. Allnu is leaning over the stern, watching. In the b.g. stands R with her hand on the throttle.

It turns right enough. But that don't  prove nothin' much. Will it stand up  under a full head of steam, that's  the question. We'll get our answer  out there -- and Lord 'elp us if it  ain't the right one.
Let's find out right now.
Why not?
Rose comes back and takes the tiller in hand. Allnutt cas off the moorings. As the bows come out into the current, gently opens the throttle.
Goodbye, darling.
He bends over the engine.
Goodbye, darling.
Neither she nor Allnutt hears the other; neither is meant to; there is a high courage in them both.
CAMERA PANS with boat as she surges out into the stream. spins around as her bows come into the river, and Rose pu the tiller across. Next moment she is flying down the str once more.

In the foreground, a spray of jungle foliage in sharp and exotic contrast to the upland pines of the last sequence. The African Queen comes into view, and CAMERA PANS with h A flock of ibis in the path of The African Queen rise on  great snowy wings, only to settle again when she has pass
looking about them.

Well, we done it, old girl. We got  down the rapids all right. I didn't  think it could be done. If it 'adn't  been for you, sweetheart, we shouldn't  be 'ere now. Don't you feel proud of  yourself, dear?

(indignantly) No, of course not. Look at the way  you made the engine go. Look how you  mended the propeller. It wasn't me  at all. (with even greater  emphasis) I don't think there's another man  alive who could have done it.
(wryly) I don't think anyone's likely to  try.
Her waters widen and a dreary, marshy, amphibious world i revealed; tree trunks and little creeper-entangled island take the place of the foaming rocks of the upper river.

Looks like this old river got tired  of all that runnin' an' jumpin' she  did an' decided to lay down an' rest  for a while... 'Ow about our doin'  the same, Rosie -- seein' as 'ow the  sun's goin' down.

Rose nods. She edges The African Queen in towards the sho Allnutt gets his boat hook into the stump of a large tree which, still half alive, grows precariously on the edge o the water with half its roots exposed. Rose goes to the boiler and starts making tea, while Alln gets a line around a root. There is hardly any current. T light is fading.
It must be right 'bout 'ere the river  changes her nyme from Ulanga to Bora. (he slaps at a mosquito) Not that it matters. Nobody lives  between 'ere and the lake. Unless  you call monkeys people.
He slaps again. There is the high frequency SOUND of  mosquitoes which fill the air.
(slapping) How much farther do you think it is  to the lake?
Oh -- not so many miles, but --
He slaps his arms and legs, get up and stands and makes s passes in the air, as though shadow-boxing.
(slapping) But what, Charlie?
(a note of hysteria  in his voice) I got a feelin' that before long  we'll wish we was shootin' the rapids  again... Ow!... Ow!

It is nightfall and the mosquitoes have left their homes the mud, under leaves, on stalks of reeds, to hunt flesh blood. They close in on Rose and Allnutt; they bite throu clothes -- they crawl under clothes; some of the smallest creep into nostrils and under eyelids. Rose and Allnutt a used to ordinary attacks, but this is beyond all experien They slap ever more wildly; they begin to show panic.
Oh!
This is awful!
(pulling at her dress) I'm going in! I'm going to get under  the water!
Yes! That's it!
But looking past Rose toward the river, he sees something that makes him grab her wrist.
No!
But I'm being eaten alive!
(pointing) Look.
on the bank.
(o.s.) What'd you say 'bout bein' eaten  alive?
And now we see that it is not one crocodile but several  submerged and partially submerged. Two slide into the wat from the bank.
After their first start at the sight of the crocs, they g back to fighting the cloud of mosquitoes that, hungry for blood, fill the air with their WHINING.
Get me out of here, Charlie! I'm  going mad!
Allnutt runs to the engine, tries to start it.
Ain't no steam. Can't start engine.
(wails) I can't stand it, Charlie!
'Ere! Lay down! Get under the canvas  there! I'll get us out into the  channel.
She obeys. Allnutt casts off, and seizing a deckboard beg to paddle. The space between the launch and the bank slow widens till at last they are in the channel. Rose peeps o from under the canvas.
Right, Rosie. We got away from 'em.  You can come out.
(crawling out) I'm ashamed, Charlie, acting like  that -- but I couldn't help it. I  was going mad.
Me, too.
You're so bitten!
Even in the faded light, his face and body show innumerab bumps.
The bites themselves ain't so bad;  it's 'avin' them all round you. I've  'eard of them sendin' buffaloes an'  native cattle stark starin' mad --  an' they run an' run till they fall  dead.
(after a pause) What are we going to do, Charlie?
Now you're asking!
Will they be like that wherever we  tie up?
Can't say.
We can't just drift all night.
If the river keeps straight an' deep  an' slow, there ain't nothin' much  can 'urt us -- I know! I'll let the  anchor out a ways. She'll stop us  before trouble gets too near.
He lets the anchor chain out, then sits on the bench. Ros leans against him. He puts his arm around her.
(after a long silence) What a time, Rosie -- what a time!  We'll never lack for stories to tell  our grandchildren -- if we live to  'ave any.
The launch seems to be floating in space, solitary as any one of the stars that are now beginning to shine and twin overhead.

The river ends in a five-mile-wide pool, fringed all the round with reeds. These reeds extend as far as the eye ca see. The boat comes down into the pool, nosing along the edge, looking for an opening. Allnutt and Rose are talking as s steers and he feeds the furnace.
Look -- maybe that's a channel. (it isn't) No.
A herd of hippopotami suddenly surface and scatter. Plung through water, mud and reeds just ahead of the boat. Behi them is left a faint indication of a channel.
What about there? (pointing) That looks like a way through.
showing a very doubtful passage into the reed bed.
Could be. (worried) I dunno. (pause) Once we get in, an' these 'ere reeds  close up be'ind our stern -- we'd  never get back, you know, Rosie.
We can't stay going round and round  out here.
If anything goes wrong a few 'undred  feet in there, we're 'eld in a trap,  you know -- till we starve or go orf  our 'eads. I dunno! (loudly. decisively) All right. Put 'er over.
Rose swings the tiller and the boat charges at the little opening in the reeds.

looking from outside. We see the boat nose into the openi In front of her the reeds part. Others are pressed under  water. But as soon as her full length is inside, the reed she has parted or submerged close together again, or rise slowly from under water. As they close, they form an  increasingly solid barrier behind her wide stern. Very so The African Queen is completely hidden from us except for the top of her tall funnel, which moves more and more slo as she goes on into the reed bed.
seen from a few feet above. A view of the endless miles o papyrus reed. At one place we see the top of the funnel o The African Queen.
the engine choking and gasping, shaking the launch. CAMER
pushing ineffectually against the knotted roots of the re which have piled up under it. There is almost no water -- just the tangled roots and an inch of liquid mud.
shutting off steam. The corners of his mouth tighten. He badly frightened. He tries to keep the fear out of his vo as he tells Rose; but we can see that Rose is desperately scared too.
It's the propeller, I think. It won't  work in this mud.
Allnutt looks down over stern. He gets up.
Where's the boat-'ook?
Allnutt finding boat hook and moving forward.
Maybe we can pull 'er along.
Allnutt reaching forward with boat hook, hooking it into  strong clumps of reeds, pulling desperately. The clumps  resist; it seems as if the boat is about to move. Then th clumps give way.
amidships, watching Allnutt.
Here! Wait a minute!

She finds a long pole or plank, chooses a good spot and b to push. After a couple of ineffectual attempts, Allnutt  hooks an especially strong clump at the same time as Rose finds a solid spot against which to push. The boat heaves and shakes, and, with a final heart-break effort on the part of Rose and Allnutt, it moves forward couple of feet.
gasping for breath, hope flickering up again.
Come on -- again!
As they resume their efforts, CAMERA DRAWS BACK, RISING T
from twenty feet above. We see the funnel of the launch  inching slowly and painfully through the reeds.
in the reeds. Rose and Allnutt are poling with their boat hooks. Even through the masks of mud they are wearing, we can see that they are both terribly haggard and exhausted
We've come along under steam, and we  paddled an' pushed 'an' pulled the  ole boat along with the 'ook. Wot we  ain't done yet is get out an' carry  'er. I spose that'll come next.
Hard to breathe! -- the air is so  wet and heavy.
Can't 'ardly tell water from land --  or for that matter, day from night.
The whole thing is like a fever dream,  isn't it?
All the channels we've lost -- an'  the twistin' we've done -- we may  come back out where we started -- if  we come out at all.
We've always followed the current,  dear -- what little there is.
That don't mean nothin' -- with this  river. This river's crazy. Crazy as  I am!
(gently) Charlie. (she touches him) We must try to keep hold of ourselves.
Sorry, old girl.
Allnutt starts pushing all the more energetically on his  pole.
Best thing to put the roses back in  our cheeks is to get out o' these  reeds.
Allnutt's exertions carry them into the shallows. The boa touches bottom. Not all of their strivings with the boath serve to move it an inch further.
(finally) What I said a while back about 'avin'  to carry the boat was meant for a  joke -- but as it turns out, I wasn't  jokin'.

Taking the painter, he goes over the side and starts pull like a draft animal. Slowly, ever so slowly, the boat beg to move, until at last she is floating again. Rose helps him back in. Suddenly she gives a cry of horri surprise.
What's the matter?
Rose can only point. As he sees what it is, Allnutt's fac contorts with panic and disgust. He makes a kind of growl horrified surprise, across which:
A couple of leeches hang to him, visibly swelling with hi blood. QUICK PULL AWAY TO TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT -- Over h line; we see 20 or 30 leeches on him.
Augh, the little beggars -- (a cracking voice) Pull 'em off me, Rosie -- no, the  heads stay -- poison yer blood.
(sudden remembrance) Salt!
She rushes to get their tin box of it.
eyes on what she is doing below SCREEN.
applied to a leech. It flinches, elongates, bunches and  swells, and drops off.
She dabs salt on the last two or three, while he stands l a partly calmed, still shocked horse.
Anythin' I hate in this world it's  leeches -- filthy devils.
He stands trembling quietly, the triangular bites still b freely. Rose dabs tenderly at one of the sinister little  wounds.

They hook the boat with great effort slowly along. The hu grazes something. They work still harder. There is a rumb SCRAPE. Then, also, a sludgy GRINDING. With the grinding, Allnutt moans as if in his sleep and t desperately to reverse direction.
(gasping) Back! 'Old 'er back --
(imitating him) Mud?
Yes.
There is too much momentum for them.
(reversing his dragging) Let's try an' get 'er over it, then.  Give 'er all you got, Rosie.
They strain enough to half kill them; the sludgy grinding intensifies.
(gasping) Good girl -- we're still makin'  'eadway -- All you got now --
Abruptly the boat comes to a dead stop.

They sit by each other, she holding his forehead; he is i dry nausea of exhaustion.
There, there, dear. There, there.  There, dear.
Able to speak, ashamed, he tries to joke.
Fine specimen of a man I am, ain't  I!
You're the bravest man that ever  lived.
He is silent, slowly and rather inanely shaking his head; she watches him.
(like a very old wife  to a very old husband) Lie down, dear. Rest. Both of us.
He keeps on shaking his head.
You just overdo, that's all. You  must take care of yourself! You're  not one bit well.
Well! We're both of us half dead.
(ignoring this) Besides, it's high time we had our  supper. It'll be dark before long.
You 'ave some. I ain't up to it yet.
Or a nice steaming cup of tea.
You fix yourself some.
Not just yet, thank you. (she gets up, taking  his hand) Come now. (she helps him weakly  up) Lie-down.
Rose helps Allnutt to the floor, and nurse-like, puts bun rags under his head.
There now. All comfy?
He tries to smile.
You rest, too.
Indeed I will. (she lies down beside  him and smiles at  him) That's all we need, a good long rest,  and we'll be on our way in a jiffy.  You'll see.
(managing a smile) Sure.
She turns her back to him because she can't meet his eyes Both lie with eyes wide open, obsessed.
(after a pause) Try to sleep, dear.
(pause) Sure. You too.
Of course.
She reaches a hand behind her and pets him. He clearly ha and resists, an impulse to take her hand. She withdraws her hand. A pause.
Rosie.
(pause; with quiet  dread) Yes, Charlie.
You want to know the truth, don't  you?
(pause; very quietly) I know it.
His eyes show deep pain.
We're finished.
That's right.
Even if we had all our strength we'd  never be able to get her off this  mud.
Not a chance in this world.

They are silent a while; everything is in their eyes. As  suddenly and swiftly as her weakness allows, she turns to him; their faces are close. CAMERA DROPS NEARER. She looks into his quiet eyes; her own eyes are fiery, no with tears but with passionate, incredulous despair;  speechless, trying to speak; a sort of palsy.
So useless!
He puts a hand along her cheek. Slowly he realizes, and  enhances for us, her only concern with dying.
They don't come no better'n you.

They lie still, looking at each other. Within about 15 seconds, their faces profoundly alter; by changes of makeup, every couple of seconds, the motionles faces become years older, and take on a kind of worn maje and gradually lose consciousness; by the end of the secon the eyes are closed. The CAMERA meanwhile very slowly  withdraws upward. In the last we can clearly see of their faces, they are quite possibly dead. As CAMERA RISES, we them at full length, as prostrated and flattened as grass pressed in a book; then, their static boat and the crawli water; the CAMERA RISES among the overhanging mangrove  branches which obscure and trap them; and, as it rises, t SCREEN slowly darkens. a real, gaping light now, visible in motion of boat and o water and of muck-flakes in water.

silently floating towards CAMERA in rustling rain, pointi slantwise, beginning to straighten.
