text: and the sun-touched last of the rain.
(o.s., softly; an  almost incapable  voice) Rose. Rosie.
He is half-up, hands on her, trying to stroke and pat her awake.
Darling. Dear.
He takes her head gently between his hands and turns her  face up to him.
Look at us, Rosie! My God just look!  We're movin', dear! We're movin'!
She opens her eyes and looks up. All she sees at first is Allnutt's face, close to her. She looks at it with devoti and with terrible sadness.
We did our best, dear.
He grabs her quite roughly into his arms and kisses her  several times, rapidly and without passion.
(talking through this) No, look, Rosie, just look at us!  We're movin', don't you see? Movin',  that's what!

And with this, as we catch her first realization and reac we leave the last of the mangroves and are among the reed gliding slowly yet freely; with a RUSTLING of reeds again the boat reminiscent of the rustling of the finished rain and the late afternoon sunlight moving through the reeds though they were harpstrings, and casting an almost rustl of slender light and shadow across their faces. Her face  becomes quietly transcendent. She gets with great difficu to her feet (she is very weak; so is he) and, reaching ov the gunwale, begins grabbing reeds and with what strength she has, tries to help them along. As soon as he realizes he gets up weakly, too, and hurries and gets the pole, cr
Easy, Rosie dear! You just rest, old  girl. Easy now.
Meanwhile, with what strength he has, he is poling. Past them and past prow, we see light beyond the high ree which steadily, slowly part for the prow and sweep past t flanks of the boat.
Both continue working; their incredulous eyes are fixed p the prow. Behind them, reeds partly close back, dark mang recede. Their eyes intensify.

The last few feet of the reeds part and the boat drifts f and clear onto a horizonless floor of golden light (or if black and white, a kind of unearthly silver); a low group wooded islands in the distance.

as they still drift, a soft breeze on them, looking aroun He sits down, obviously because he feels too weak to stan Rose, still standing, looks towards him, waiting his auth to believe what she already knows. They speak quietly, as someone were asleep.
It -- really is?
He reaches out his hand to her.
Come on -- sit down, old girl. Yer  tremblin' like a leaf.

But she gets down quietly onto her knees and bows her hea He looks at her a few moments, then a little uneasily and shyly, gets down onto his knees. She begins to cry very d and silently; we don't see her face. Allnutt puts his arm around her, and she hides her face against him and cries, audibly now but quietly, taking his free hand in her own.
(very quietly) There, there, Rosie. There, old girl.  We're all right now, dear. There,  there.
It's like Heaven.
By Allnutt's face, it is better than that, but he knows w she means.
(in a queer voice) God let us live.
Musta been 'Im, all right -- 'tweren't  nothin' in our power.
A pause.
(quiet, charged voice) It wasn't for our sakes, either.
(pause; carefully) 'Ow you mean, Rosie?
He brought us here to do His work.

She gets to her feet and walks past CAMERA towards bow. ROSE -- (PAST BOW) as she comes up, Allnutt following. Sh is looking all around, and past her we see only empty wat and empty sky. She begins to look impatient.
(quietly) Rosie, this lake's an 'undred miles  long; forty wide, at the biggest. It  might be days afore she comes our  way.
Then start the fire. We'll go find  her.
No, Rosie, we won't 'ave to go out  of our way. She'll come to us.
Come to us?
Patrolin' the lake. She's bound to  come by, don't you never worry. An'  when she does, we want to be well  'id.
Hmmm. Perhaps you're right.
Sure I am. So let's just cruise about  a bit till we find a good 'idin'  place, an' then we'll lay in wait  fer 'er. Right?
Right.
They go back towards engine. TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as, Rose watching almost wit reverence, Allnutt strikes a match and touches it to the  carefully prepared wood.

THE CURLING SMOKE -- (FROM THEIR VIEWPOINT) and catching  flame and the SOUNDS -- an image almost of resurrection. ROSE AND ALLNUTT -- (FROM FIRE'S ANGLE) their faces  revitalizing, as light of flame works on them over increa SOUND of fire; he gently shuts the furnace door, and adju the draft; the fire begins a really happy ROARING. Allnut looks up and around across the water, clearly figuring wh they might cruise around.
(murmuring) Let's -- see. We might, uh --

His eyes sharpen into great intentness on something very  distant. All of a sudden he picks up a bailing pail, dips it full, and douses the fire. TWO SHOT -- ROSE (PAST ALLNUTT) Rose looks at him amazed. gestures silently with a jerk of his head. She walks towa CAMERA and looks. LONG SHOT -- THE LAKE Almost invisibly small on the horiz a small black smudge, a gleaming white speck, which sharp like a fresh star as we look.
(o.s.) That's The Louisa.
CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT He gets up on the gunwale.
Yes, that's The Louisa all right.
Which way are they going?
They're comin' this way.
(forcing herself to  be calm) They mustn't see us here. Can we get  far enough among the reeds for them  not to see us?
Got to work fast.
Pulling and tugging with the boat hooks, they swing the l around and head her into the reeds.
We'll have to cut some down. How  deep is the mud?

Knife in hand, Allnutt goes over the bows among the reeds WIDER SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as he goes over the bows. sinks in the mud until the surface of the water is up to armpits. Floundering about, he cuts every reed within rea Then, pulling on the bow painter, he is able to work the  launch up into the cleared space.
There's still a bit of her sticking  out.

She throws a desperate glance towards The Louisa, which i making good time, and is less than half the former distan away. Allnutt splashes back among the reeds and goes on cutting and hauling. Rose helps him to get back on board. He is i state of near collapse from his exertions. He lies on the deck panting while Rose cranes her neck over the reeds.
(o.s.) She's coming right toward us, Charlie!

CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Groaning, Allnutt staggers his knees, then to his feet. Together they watch the appr of The Louisa. LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA white, spotless, beautiful. At he stern floats the flag of the Imperial German Navy. On her foredeck, we can pick out the six-pound gun which gives t Germans command of the lake. We can see the figures of sa moving about on the deck. Over the SOUND of her engines comes a smartly given order following which The Louisa alters her course by a point o two. CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Allnutt groans again, this time from relief.
They're going a different way now.
I thought they'd seen us.
LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA heading toward some little island in the middle of the lake.

They're makin' for them islands to  anchor for the night. They'll go on  in the mornin'. But don't you worry.  They'll come 'ere again. You just  see if they don't. You know 'ow  Germans are; they lays down systems  an' they sticks to 'em. Mondays  they're at one place. Tuesdays  somewheres else. Wednesdays p'raps  they're 'ere. Same ole round, week  after week. You know.
LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA as the SOUND of her engines cease
(o.s.) Look! Wot did I tell ya! She's  droppin' 'er anchor.
(nods) How long will it take to get the  torpedoes ready?

I can get the stuff into the tubes  in no time, as you might say. Don't  know 'bout the detonators. Gotta  make them up, you see -- devise  something. Then we got to cut 'oles  in the bows. Might 'ave it all done  in three days. Depends on them  detonators.
Rose receives this information in silence. Her eyes remai on The Louisa, now lying at anchor.
Rosie, old girl -- Rosie --
(a faraway note in  her voice) Yes, dear.

I know wot you're thinkin' 'bout  doin'. (he takes her hand  and presses it) You're thinkin' 'bout takin' The  African Queen out at night next time  The Louisa comes 'ere, ain't you,  old girl? (Rose nods) We ought to manage it.

PAN SHOT -- ALLNUTT'S HAND as it takes one of the package out of the box and carries it to one of the cylinders and places it inside. A wrench and the cylinder head are in v lying on the deck. Allnutt's face comes into the SCREEN. He puts more packag into the cylinder. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Allnutt and Rose in TWO SHOT Leaning over the side, Rose brings up handfuls of mud fro the bottom and dumps it on the deck. Allnutt carries the  sticky stuff to the cylinder and drops it in.

INSERT: A DISC OF WOOD IN ALLUTT'S HAND. Three holes have been punched through it. Allnutt's fingers fit cartridges into them. Then a second disc of the same diameter is pla over the first. The second disc has three nails in it. It turned so that a nail point rests on the percussion cap o each cartridge.
(o.s.) Ought to work all right.
He begins to screw the pair of discs together. CAMERA PUL BACK revealing Rose and Allnutt intent upon his handiwork
Can't put them into the cylinders  yet. They're a bit tricky. We can  put 'em in when we're all ready to  start.
It will be dark then, of course.  Will you be able to do it in the  dark?
Case of have to... (he puts the detonators  away in the locker) Better get the cylinders into place  now.
With Rose's help he drags and pushes one of the cylinders forward.

CLOSE SHOT -- THE BOW The cylinders in position, projecti like cannon through two holes on either side of the stem  just above the waterline. o.s., the SOUND of hammering. The CAMERA RAISES and DOLLIES FORWARD TO: CLOSE SHOT --  ALLNUTT -- SHOOTING at him over Rose's shoulder. He is na the cylinders solidly into position with battens torn fro provision cases. Finally, the work done to his satisfacti he tosses the hammer aside.
Well, old girl -- I done it all now.  Everything. We're all ready.
It is a solemn moment. He shakes his head.
(reminiscently) You know I been thinkin'. There ain't  no need for us both to -- to do it.  Now I've 'ad time to study it, I can  plainly see it's a one-man job.
You couldn't be more right, Charlie  dear.
Glad you agree, Rosie. When the time  comes I'll put you ashore on the  south side of the lake and you wait  for me while I attend to The Louisa...
(interrupting) Certainly not! You're the one to be  put ashore.
Of course, you. This whole thing was  my idea, wasn't it?... I'm the logical  one to carry it out.
Why, Rose! I'm surprised! You're a  very sensible woman as a rule. Now  we won't 'ave no more talk along  those lines.
I can manage this launch every bit  as well as you, Charlie Allnutt, and  you know it!
Rosie, you're cracked!
Didn't I steer going down the rapids?

Oh, you steered well enough. But you  don't know nothin' about the engine.  Spose she broke down on you out there  in the middle of the lake? Where  would you be? But me, I'd leave the  tiller and go and do a thing or two  to the engine -- you know, spit on  'er or kick 'er in the belly -- an'  she'd go right to work again. She  knows 'oo 'er boss is, you bet, that  ole engine does.
(defeated) All right, Charlie. I guess you have  to be there.
Well, now, that's more like it. I'll  dive off a second or two before the  crash and swim over to where you'll  be waitin' on the north shore.
Charlie...
Yes.
No need of our pretending.
I don't know wot you're talkin' about.
Oh, yes you do. There's got to be a  hand on that tiller right up to the  last.
Allnutt would like to protest; he opens his mouth to do s but no words issue. He falls into a stricken silence.
(continuing) Don't you understand, dear? I wouldn't  care about going on to Nairobi --  without you.
Having no words, Allnutt can only nod.
(continuing) We'll do it together. It will be you  at the engine and me at the tiller,  as it has been from the start.
(in a choked voice) Right.
When you come to think of it, we're  a very lucky couple, really.
Aren't we just.
Charlie.
Yes, dear.
Let's make The African Queen as clean  as we can. Let's scrub her decks and  polish her brass.
(in quick agreement) I've got a can o' paint for 'er mast.  She ought to look 'er best. 'Er very  best. Representin' as she does the  Royal Navy.

MEDIUM SHOT -- THE AFRICAN QUEEN Quite a transformation h taken place in her appearance. Her decks are clean, her b polished. Rose is engaged in painting her stumpy mast. He old boiler shines like a mirror. In fact, Allnutt is usin it as such while he shaves.
(between strokes of  the razor) I wish I 'ad somethin' clean to put  on. It don't seem right for the ship's  captain to be without pants.
Charlie...
Yes, dear.
I have a pair you can wear.
You mean a pair o' yours?
What's the difference?
Well, you're the one'll have to look  at me.
She gives them to him. Getting into them, Allnutt begins laugh. When he reveals himself to Rose, it is with obviou embarrassment. He assumes a position rather like Septembe Morn's.
Here. Put this on, too. (she displays one of  her singlets)
Ain't that goin' a bit too far?
Don't be silly!

He takes it and puts it on. He looks intently at Rose,  expecting ridicule. Her eyes are not on him; they are on horizon. LONG SHOT -- A PUFF OF SMOKE AND A WHITE DOT The Louisa. TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as she stares at the horizon His eyes follow hers.

CLOSE SHOT -- A CYLINDER -- (NIGHT) as Allnutt's hands fi fitting a detonator into its fore-end, tapping around its edges with a hammer. He is in the water. CAMERA PANS with him around the bow to the other cylinder. Rose passes dow the second detonator. Allnutt puts it into place and pull himself up over the side. He goes to the boiler which cas a red glow on the surrounding deck, and inspects the gaug Steam is up. He looks across the waters of the lake towar the little group of islands. LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA A bundle of faint lights in the  distance. TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as a sudden gust of wind str the surrounding reeds, causing them to bend and toss. All takes Rose in his arms. Clinging to one another, they kis try to speak; fail -- then separate.
Blowing up a bit. We better get  started. All right?
All right.

He unfastens the side painter, then takes the boat hook a thrusts it against a clump of reeds. The African Queen mo slowly out into the fairway. Allnutt lays the boat hook d feels for the throttle valve and opens it. The propeller  begins its beat and the engine its muffled clanking. FULL SHOT -- THE AFRICAN QUEEN coming out of the reeds in the lake. TWO SHOT -- ALLNUTT AND ROSE Allnutt is staring at the bo scowling.
(observes his  expression with  anxiety) Is something the matter, dear?
'Er bows are ridin' awful low for  this kind o' water. Them 'eavy  cylinders are what's doin' it.
A wave splashes over the bows into the boat, so that her  decks swim in water.
Got to get 'er nose way up 'igh or  we'll be in trouble.
He begins shifting ballast into the stern of the boat, wh is swaying and staggering about in haphazard fashion.
We've been through worse.
Rivers is one thing -- open water  another. She ain't built for it. Not  when it's rough.
He goes to the engine, begins to tinker with it for a mom
steering. She is calm, resolute. Allnutt comes back into  SHOT. His brows are working.
Rosie.
Yes, Charlie.

This 'ere storm is messing things up  a bit. 'Er bows 'ave got to ride  'igh or we'll be swamped before we  get 'alf way to The Louisa. On the  other 'and, they've got to be low  when we 'it 'er, so' the explosion  will be down at 'er waterline.
Can anything be done?
(nodding) Just before we 'it, I'll bring the  ballast back forrard.
Goodbye, darling.
Goodbye, sweetheart darling...
A wave breaks over the side, drenching them both.
Blimey!

It rolls extravagantly as a wind of incredible speed whip down on the lake and rouses the shallow waters to maniaca fury. A series of waves come crashing against the flat si Then suddenly the darkness is torn away by a dazzling fla of lightning which reveals the wild waters around them.  Thunder follows with a loud BANG like a thousand cannon f at once. Then comes the rain pouring down through the  blackness in solid rivers. The wind abates momentarily, but the surface of the lake  still heaves. The boat begins to pound, raising her bows  high out of the water and bringing them down again with a shattering CRASH. Allnutt seizes a pail and begins to bail furiously, but t no purpose. Now the wind strikes from a new quarter, laying its grip the torn surface of the lake and building it up into  mountains.

numbed and stupefied, but struggling to maintain her hold the tiller. Suddenly Allnutt is at her side, putting her through a life buoy. They totter and sway for a long mome then the stern of the launch is engulfed by a heavy wave, and they are up to their waists in water. The African Que is swamped. Very slowly she capsizes. In the distance we the lights of The Louisa, safe at anchor.

The CAPTAIN and FOUR of the SHIP'S OFFICERS constitute th court in a proceeding against a small man dressed in woma bloomers and a ragged singlet. The latter stands, chin on his chest, gazing dully at the carpet. The CAPTAIN is President of the court, of course. He is a corpulent man with whiskers, groomed in imitation of von  Triplitz. Behind him on the wall is a portrait in oils of the Kaiser. He keeps his eyes closed throughout the  proceedings. To the Captain's right, stands the ship's FIRST OFFICER, is acting as prosecutor. He is clean-shaven, dark, with p blue eyes; his manner is rigidly correct. To the Captain' left, sits the ship's SECOND OFFICER, who is serving as  defense counsel. (in broken English) What is your nationality?
Allnutt does nothing to indicate he hears the question.
French?... Belgian?... English?
(thickly) English.
Your name?
Charles Allnutt.
What were you doing on the island? (Allnutt remains  sullenly silent)
The punishment for not answering the court is hanging.
